Award.AwardTitle: Multiplayer Board Game Strategies in the Introductory CS Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research has demonstrated that learning to program in context, especially a context that students are familiar with, increases student motivation. This project explores the context of traditional board games. Unlike modern computer games, board games are inherently discrete. The board has a fixed number of allowed positions for the game pieces and each player performs a mental search through a finite number of possible moves to decide the next action. Designing an automated player strategy for a board game provides a natural context for basic data structures and search algorithms covered in CS 1 and CS 2.

For this project, researchers are developing software scaffolding to allow students to implement computer-based versions of actual board games. The game engines are responsible for the graphical user interface, rule enforcement and round-robin calling of the individual player strategies. Students design and implement player strategies to compete with a basic strategy provided by the instructor or more advanced strategies provided by other students. Three game engines are being developed in both Java and Python programming languages. Collaborations include a research university, a liberal arts college and an institute of technology. At least four hundred students are expected to use the materials during the project. Use beyond the project lifetime is expected because materials will be available on the Web and workshops are provided in the final project year to help faculty at other institutions adopt the materials. Project goals including student motivation and performance are evaluated by an evaluation team including three external experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve undergraduate education in computer science through open-ended projects that increase student motivation for the area. Each of these projects is centered around a well-established board game that demonstrates typical CS2 topics in a natural context. In traditional game-based assignments the students implement a rule checker for the game. In contrast, these projects ask each student team to design and implement their own player strategy. At the end of the term the strategies can face each other in a friendly tournament. The students need to use the concepts from the CS2 course in order to generate a valid move for their player. However, they also have the opportunity to keep experimenting with their strategy, creating an open-ended project that targets a varied group of students: some choose to use a simple strategy while others go well beyond the course material in order to design the most successful strategy.

The deliverables of this project include supporting software, documentation, and the assignment descriptions for four board games: Gobblet by Thierry Denoual and published by Blue Orange Games, Quoridor by Mirko Marchesi and published by Gigamic, San Francisco Cable Cars by Dirk Henn and published by QueenGames, and The aMAZEing Labyrinth by Max J. Kobbert and published by Ravensburger. These games were selected for their relation to introductory computer science concepts: the last three are maze-like games that require a variety of search algorithms and clever data structure representation, while the first is an interesting variant of Tic-Tac-Toe that involves manipulation of and searching through 2D arrays. The Gobblet game is a shorter project option, adoptable also in high school setting.

The hypothesis of this project was that programming player strategies means that the students enjoy the project more, score higher, and are better motivated and equipped to study computer science, when compared to traditional well-defined (i.e. not open-ended) game programming projects. The project evaluation employed a randomized, controlled trial methodology, where the study group designed and implemented player strategies while the control group implemented a rule checker for the same board game. The study confirmed higher enjoyment and interest of the study group participants. It did not show any statistically significant differences among the other measured quantities, for example grade distribution, of the respective groups.

The project has been used by over 2000 undergraduate students and more than twenty instructors at at least five universities and two high schools. It employed two undergraduate student developers and two additional student helpers. It was disseminated via blind-reviewed and refereed conference publications, posters, presentations, workshops, and tutorials. The project also provided exposure to science and technology for a wider Rochester community through the annual ImagineRIT festival, attended each year by about 30,000 visitors, many of whom are middle and high school students.
